name: treatment of waste plastic, consumer electronics, manual dismantling, sorting and cleaning, informal sector | waste plastic, consumer electronics, sorted | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/21607/documentation

New Delhi informal plastic recycling market is South Asia's largest recycling hub. The raw material is collected from all parts of the country. The informal sector works on its large collection network of ragpickers and kabbadiwalas present throughout the country. It is known to be one of the most efficient collection channels due to its reach to every household in the country and efficient sorting techniques. When the plastic is collected by informal recyclers, dismantling, sorting and clean-up of plastics from e-waste is carried out manually, with minimal or no safe working conditions to the workers and with no proper disposal and treatment techniques. Recyclers adopt different techniques of identification and segregation of different plastics e.g. by noise of breaking plastics, smell of burning and salt water bath. Mixed plastic undergoes salt water bath method for cleaning and segregation of different plastics.

This dataset include activities that occur once the material is received by the informal sector for further processing.

This dataset includes activities until the received waste plastics is segregated, dismantled and sorted manually.
category: E:Water supply; sewerage, waste management and remediation activities/38:Waste collection, treatment and disposal activities; materials recovery/383:Materials recovery/3830:Materials recovery

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The recycling sector has been following this method for several years. There is no anticipated change in the next few years in their method of working. However, with the new e-waste rules in the country, certain changes are expected to occur over a period of time, however, may not be earlier than 2022.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The geography included for the informal sector mainly includes the recycling hub at New Delhi. However, since country's majority of the recycling happens in this hub, the data set can be considered complete.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The informal sector uses equipment that it has been utilizing for several years. The equipment are generally assembled ones and do not refer to any particular supplier. Hence it can be considered as an old technology.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: The geography included for the informal sector mainly includes the recycling hub at New Delhi. However, since country's majority of the recycling happens in this hub, the data set can be considered complete.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: An initial data collection questionnaire was circulated amongst the recyclers. On-site visits were carried out and data were collected from 15 different recyclers in the informal recycling sector. These recyclers were engaged into recycling of plastics mainly Polycarbonate (PC), High Impact Polystyrene (HIPS), Acrylonitrile Butadiene Styrene (ABS), Polypropylene (PP) etc. Information provided was verified. Data collected from different recyclers were compiled in the excel sheets and analysed All the data were aggregated to per 1000 kgs of treatment of plastics.

exchanges.description: This exchange represents the cleaned and sorted material used by formal and informal plastic recycling sectors in India. These recyclers are engaged into recycling of different plastic types from e-waste/WEEE, mainly Polycarbonate (PC), High Impact Polystyrene (HIPS), Acrylonitrile Butadiene Styrene (ABS), Poly Propylene (PP) etc.
